title: Prompr: AI Agent Workflow Automation Library
description: Comprehensive workflow automation library enabling parallel multi-agent task execution with Claude AI, featuring intelligent task distribution, automatic progress tracking, and seamless Git integration for streamlined development workflows.
longDescription:
Prompr is a sophisticated workflow automation library designed to transform software development through intelligent AI agent orchestration. The library enables developers to harness the power of multiple Claude AI agents working in parallel, automatically distributing tasks, tracking progress, and managing complex development workflows.

Built with a focus on practical software development needs, Prompr bridges the gap between AI capabilities and real-world project requirements. The library provides structured commands for everything from Product Requirements Document generation to multi-agent task execution, making it an essential tool for teams looking to integrate AI-powered automation into their development pipeline.

The system demonstrates advanced agentic capabilities through its ability to coordinate multiple AI agents, handle task dependencies, and maintain project context across complex workflows. With built-in Git integration and automatic progress tracking, Prompr transforms how development teams approach project planning and execution.
features: Multi-agent parallel task execution with 3-5 concurrent agents
Intelligent task distribution and dependency handling
Automatic Git integration with commit generation
Dynamic task list creation from requirements
Progress tracking and monitoring across all agents
Context management for complex project workflows
Extensible command architecture for custom workflows
challenges: Coordinating multiple AI agents while maintaining task coherence
Managing context and state across distributed agent workflows
Creating intuitive command patterns for complex operations
Ensuring reliable Git integration with automatic commits
Handling workflow interruptions and resume capabilities

codeSnippets.title: Task Distribution Engine
codeSnippets.code:
class MultiAgentTaskDistributor:
    """Intelligently distributes tasks across multiple Claude agents"""
    
    def __init__(self, max_agents: int = 5):
        self.max_agents = max_agents
        self.active_agents = []
        self.task_queue = []
        self.completed_tasks = []
        
    async def distribute_tasks(self, tasks: List[Task]) -> None:
        """Distribute tasks across available agents with dependency handling"""
        # Analyze task dependencies
        dependency_graph = self._build_dependency_graph(tasks)
        
        # Sort tasks by priority and dependencies
        sorted_tasks = self._topological_sort(dependency_graph)
        
        # Create agent pool
        agents = await self._initialize_agents(self.max_agents)
        
        # Distribute tasks with load balancing
        for task in sorted_tasks:
            if self._dependencies_satisfied(task):
                agent = self._get_least_busy_agent(agents)
                await self._assign_task(agent, task)
            else:
                self.task_queue.append(task)
    
    async def _assign_task(self, agent: ClaudeAgent, task: Task) -> None:
        """Assign task to specific agent with progress tracking"""
        try:
            # Create task context with all necessary information
            context = TaskContext(
                task=task,
                project_state=self.project_state,
                previous_outputs=self._get_related_outputs(task)
            )
            
            # Execute task with the agent
            result = await agent.execute_task(context)
            
            # Process result and update project state
            await self._process_task_result(task, result)
            
            # Check if new tasks can be started
            await self._check_queue_for_ready_tasks()
            
        except Exception as e:
            await self._handle_task_failure(task, e)
    
    def _build_dependency_graph(self, tasks: List[Task]) -> Dict:
        """Build task dependency graph for intelligent scheduling"""
        graph = {}
        
        for task in tasks:
            graph[task.id] = {
                'task': task,
                'dependencies': task.dependencies,
                'dependents': [],
                'status': 'pending'
            }
        
        # Build dependent relationships
        for task_id, task_info in graph.items():
            for dep_id in task_info['dependencies']:
                if dep_id in graph:
                    graph[dep_id]['dependents'].append(task_id)
        
        return graph
    
    async def _monitor_progress(self) -> None:
        """Monitor and report progress across all agents"""
        while self._has_active_tasks():
            progress = self._calculate_progress()
            
            print(f"Progress: {progress['completed']}/{progress['total']} tasks")
            print(f"Active agents: {len(self.active_agents)}")
            print(f"Queue length: {len(self.task_queue)}")
            
            await asyncio.sleep(5)  # Update every 5 seconds

codeSnippets.title: Git Integration with Auto-Commit
codeSnippets.code:
class GitWorkflowManager:
    """Manages Git operations for automated workflow commits"""
    
    def __init__(self, repo_path: str):
        self.repo_path = repo_path
        self.git = GitPython.Repo(repo_path)
        
    async def auto_commit_task_completion(self, task: Task, changes: List[str]) -> None:
        """Automatically commit changes when task completes"""
        try:
            # Stage all changes
            for file_path in changes:
                self.git.index.add([file_path])
            
            # Generate intelligent commit message
            commit_message = await self._generate_commit_message(task, changes)
            
            # Create commit with detailed information
            commit = self.git.index.commit(
                message=commit_message,
                author=Actor("Prompr AI", "prompr@ai-workflow.dev")
            )
            
            print(f"âœ… Auto-committed changes: {commit.hexsha[:8]}")
            print(f"ðŸ“ Message: {commit_message}")
            
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"âŒ Git operation failed: {e}")
            # Continue workflow without failing
    
    async def _generate_commit_message(self, task: Task, changes: List[str]) -> str:
        """Generate contextual commit message using Claude"""
        change_summary = self._analyze_changes(changes)
        
        prompt = f"""
        Generate a concise, professional Git commit message for the following task completion:
        
        Task: {task.title}
        Description: {task.description}
        Files modified: {', '.join(changes)}
        Change summary: {change_summary}
        
        Follow conventional commit format: type(scope): description
        Keep it under 72 characters for the first line.
        """
        
        # Use Claude to generate commit message
        response = await self.claude_client.complete(prompt)
        return response.strip()
    
    def create_workflow_branch(self, workflow_name: str) -> str:
        """Create dedicated branch for workflow execution"""
        branch_name = f"prompr-workflow-{workflow_name}-{int(time.time())}"
        
        # Create and checkout new branch
        new_branch = self.git.create_head(branch_name)
        new_branch.checkout()
        
        print(f"ðŸŒ¿ Created workflow branch: {branch_name}")
        return branch_name
    
    def finalize_workflow(self, branch_name: str) -> None:
        """Finalize workflow and prepare for merge"""
        # Switch back to main branch
        self.git.heads.main.checkout()
        
        print(f"ðŸŽ¯ Workflow completed on branch: {branch_name}")
        print(f"ðŸ’¡ To merge: git merge {branch_name}")
